results.title: Wives' tales
results.creator_credit: Claire Forster and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
280 families were affected by the deployment of the 7th and 8th battalion with INTERFET (UN Sanctioned International Force in East Timor). For the women and families left behind, there was a pressing need for group support. Shying away from a tag such as “the army wives club,” Patti-Jane Gould established the P.I.T. crew - Partners In Timor. The women of this support network speak candidly of the impact their partners departure has had on them and their children, how it feels to say goodbye, their fears, and how they adjust when life returns to “normal.” Army personnel share their fears and thoughts too and how their lives have changed since Timor. Finally, we share an emotional reunion on the docks. Introduced by Lieutenant General Peter Cosgrove.

results.title: Witness to the American experience
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Developing image”.
Examines the importance of photographs as an historical record of the American experience, and suggests that care must be taken in accepting the photographs as unbiased or entirely realistic. Viewers visit American Civil War locations as they look today and compare them to historical records. Through photographs, the emotions of a community deep in economical and psychological depression at the turn-of-the-century, are highlighted.

results.title: Witness to history
results.creator_credit: Susan Eikov Green and Guidance Associates
results.brief_description: This series of four progams examines different aspects of 20th. century history. ‘Turn of the century America’ looks at the United States and the major changes which occured from 1890-1920. ‘The Russian Revolution’ features archival footage depicting this historic event. ‘WW2-The dark years in Europe’ covers the events which led to the outbreak of war in Western Europe’ ‘Europe after WW2’ looks at a range of events which shaped post-war Europe.

results.title: Witness to Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Robin Taylor
results.brief_description: This program describes the events behind the gates of Auschwitz using archival footage and photographs. This program documents the experiences of Rudolph Verba, one of the few to escape Auschwitz and co-author the report which unveiled the horror of the Nazi work camps.

results.title: Without you I'm nothing
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Krane, M.C.E.G. and John Boskovich
results.brief_description: Based on Sandra Bernhard’s one-woman live show, “Without You I’m Nothing” is an ecstatic celebration of deviancy and sexual difference. Bernhard is a sardonic and biting comedian who in a series of inspired personas exposes the hypocrisy and shallowness that dominate contemporary American culture. Whether sending up her suburban Jewish upbringing or the excesses of Hollywood stardom, Bernhard’s stand-up routines reclaim the transgressive bitchiness of camp. “Without You I’m Nothing” achieves much of its power from the sheer force of Bernhard’s personality. Whether performing a lesbian-tinted “Me and Mrs Jones” or stripping to “Do You Want To Funk?”, her energy is explosive and exhilarating to watch. For lesbian and gay viewers, there is also the elation of watching a performer unapologetically celebrate the unique mixture of the kitsch, the erotic and the subversive which is central to queer notions of community and identity. The film also celebrates the pivotal contribution of African-Americans to popular music, and acknowledges how this contribution has been largely stripped of its innovation and urgency when exploited by white performers. Wicked, intelligent, sophisticated and fun, “Without You I’m Nothing” is a key work of the new Queer Cinema.

results.title: Without prejudice
results.brief_description: The facts about epilepsy are contrasted with popular misconceptions. The theme is the need for unbiased attitudes towards people with epilepsy. Children who have epilepsy are shown talking about their problems. The effect that public ignorance has on people with epilepsy is clearly illustrated.
results.description: The facts about epilepsy are contrasted with popular misconceptions. The theme is the need for unbiased attitudes towards people with epilepsy. results.title: Without love = Bez milosci [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Zespoly Filmowe, Iluzjon Film Unit and Barbara Sass
results.brief_description: Pill-popping reporter Ewa Bracka (Dorota Stalinska), needs her uppers to fuel her all-consuming non-stop attempts at getting “the story”. Her determination to be a top journalist has no boundaries - cynical, ruthless, unethical, and unscrupulous, Ewa is prepared to sleep her way to the top. As Ewa herself says “The object of life is to live. To have it all and at any price”. Ewa is a single parent, living in Warsaw with her young daughter (the result of an affair whilst in Rome). With the help and support of her mother in caring for her daughter, Ewa is able to pursue her career, take up judo lessons and maintain the odd affair or two. Ewa believes in the issue, but has no time for the people, innocent or guilty, whom she may expose in getting her story on to the front page. That is until she meets and befriends Marianna, a young girl who lives and works in a local brothel. Through Marianna, Ewa is finally forced to confront her own demons. Cast includes Wladyslaw Kowalski, Malgorzata Zajaczkowska, Zdzislaw Wardejn, Emilian Kaminski, Jadwiga Polanowska, Malgorzata Pritulak. In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: Without consent
results.brief_description: Attempts to gain an understanding of sexually related violence in Australia. “Every woman’s fear. Part 1”: Examines the impact of a rape which occurred in Broadford Victoria in March 1991. The effects of sexual assault on victims, their families and the community are shown through poignant interviews with victims, police and counsellors. “The Dark Side. Part 2”: Provides an insight into the mind of the rapist with offenders describing their motivations, emotions and their view of the victim. Contains a powerful interview with a victim of male sexual assault.
